text: Going to start moving announcements and bug-updates to this clean channel, just to make sure they can be seen. Thank you for your patience as we try to make the server more useful. Your suggestions are always welcome.

**New Homeworlds click handler now active.** Thank you all Homeworlds players, and in particular @mneme , for your concrete suggestions about how to improve the Homeworlds experience. A new click handler is now available alongside the old one. The old one only gets triggered if you're entering moves in a combination of typing and clicking or if you're continuing a string of sacrifice moves. Most moves, however, are now reduced to 1 to 3 clicks, as follows:
```txt
enemy -> ATTACK
friendly > same friendly -> BUILD
friendly > stash -> TRADE
friendly > system -> MOVE
friendly > VOID (the space between systems) > stash -> DISCOVER
```

The help text has been similarly updated. I've done a fair bit of testing, but there are always edge cases. Please let me know if you run into any trouble, and I remain open to further discussion on how to make things better. Thanks for playing with us!

**Testers wanted for new game Wizard's Garden!** Another of the games we're migrating over from SDG 1.0. A pair of wizards vye to harvest reagents in a single garden plot. You play until no more planting is possible, and whoever harvested the most wins! Because lots can happen in a reversi-style game, I'm trialing a new approach. Each move is presented across four boards. The top-left shows the piece placement, the top-right shows the flipping, the bottom-left shows any harvests, and the bottom-right is where you actually make your move. I can't label the individual boards at this point, but hopefully it's sufficiently clear. The help text tries to be helpful. **Testers wanted for new game Armadas!** (Tagging suggesters, @Nienna and @Samraku ). I know this isn't a more traditional abstract, but my inner math nerd wanted to play. More traditional fare is on the way. 

Armadas is a miniatures-style game of naval combat played with Looney pyramids. 2-4 commanders move their fleet on an open field trying to eliminate their opponents. These sorts of games tend to have a *lot* of house rules and add-ons. I'm certainly open to expanding this over time, but for now there are three scenarios: (1) the default is trio against trio, (2) there's also a "two trio" variant, and (3) the "freeform" variant lets players place as many pieces as they want until both players pass. This requires good-faith communication in advance.

When issuing an "open" or "standing" challenge, there is now a "duration" field. It defaults to `0`, which means that the challenge will remain active until you revoke it, no matter how many people accept it. But you can now change it to any number. After that many times people accept your challenge, the challenge will be automatically removed. So setting it to `1` means the challenge will expire once it is accepted the first time.

For reasons, this can only be extended to 2-player games. Maybe one day we'll find a way around that.

I am *very* excited to announce the availability of browser push notifications. **Push notifications are 100% optional!** Each browser/device has its own process for allowing/blocking push notifications. If you aren't getting notifications, the first thing to do is check your browser's documentation. If you're getting notifications but they are "weird" in some way, do let us know.

We've tried to minimize the amount of spam. There are only four types of notification (game start, your turn, game end, challenges), and later instances of the same type will simply overwrite the earlier ones, so you'll never have more than four notifications active at one time. Clicking a notification will open the associated URL, focusing you on an existing tab if one exists. And if you receive a notification while already actively using the site, you'll instead get a "toast" notification in the top-right corner of the screen.

There is one drawback: activating these notifications brings along with it a bunch of progressive web app stuff that can interfere with getting the most recent versions of front-end code. In some cases, a hard refresh is not enough. You'll instead need to close all Abstract Play tabs and then reopen. I don't have a good sense of how problematic this will be. I guess we'll find out together! üôÇ Thank you for your patience. Bug reports and suggestions for improvement are always welcome.

Basically, you can draw your first line anywhere, and the system will only hold you up if a second line is legally possible. Hope that's clear üôÇ Let me know if you run into any issues.

@Game Designer, in particular @Drew Edwards (Coldsalmon): I have added peer-to-peer networking to the designer. If you don't need it, you can just collapse and ignore the networking stuff at the very top. I may find a way to hide it more fully if people find it truly irksome. For those that have said they will use it ( üëÄ @Drew Edwards (Coldsalmon) ), it's relatively straightforward. Simply share your connection ID with friends. They enter that ID in their own browser and it will connect the two of you directly. You can then manually pass around a "talking stick." Whoever has the talking stick is in control, and their game state is forcibly sent to everyone else. It's not particularly robust, but it seems to fundamentally work. SDG-style "standing challenges" are now available:
- The front-facing nomenclature for challenges has been changed to simply "open" challenges (those that anybody can accept) and "closed" (ones you issue to specific opponents).
- The term "standing challenge" is now being used to refer to a longstanding request that you configure for challenges of specific games.
- At the bottom of your dashboard is a new table and button. A standing challenge works like most other challenges but also has a "limit" and a "sensitivity."
  - The limit is the maximum number of matching active games you want.
  - The sensitivity refers to how "matching" is determined. If it's set to "meta," then it counts *all* different active games you have for that specific game type. The setting "variants" also takes into account the specific variants you selected.
- Twice a day, the system will look at all existing standing challenges. It will count up all the active games you are currently participating in that match the sensitivity of the challenge. If the number of active games is below your limit, and you have no matching open challenges already, then it will issue a single open challenge for that game + variant combination.
- You can suspend and delete the standing challenges themselves, but suspending a challenge does not automatically revoke any challenges currently open.

Let me know if something does not work as you expect or if you have any questions or further suggestions. Thanks!

We have now reached 200 games, and more are on the way! I know some feel this is too many, so I thought I might take this opportunity to clarify my goals:
- I'm a librarian at heart, so first and foremost I want to create a place where a wide array of abstracts can be enjoyed. I have no upper limit in mind.
- This a noncommercial, open source exercise. As long as hosting costs are covered, and someone is around to keep things going, the site will remain free to enjoy.
- Because we are not chasing growth and financial gain, and we rely on volunteer effort, that means there will be ups and downs in developer activity. We encourage continued use of the #suggestions and #bug-reports channels, and as long as I'm around, those will be chipped away at. If you open your user settings panel (the cog icon next to your username, either at the top-right corner of your screen or in the "hamburger" menu on smaller screens), there is now an option to disable tournament start and end emails. This has been long requested, and I apologize for it taking so long to add. It's hard to validate small changes like this, so do let me know if you keep getting emails after disabling the setting. I'll note that tournament starts and ends are *only* announced by email. There is no other avenue currently to know that a tournament has ended other than actively monitoring the page. Two changes:
- There is now a [`/play`](https://play.abstractplay.com/play) route that will immediately take you to the next game in your queue (or to the dashboard if you have no available games). This also populates the "next game" queue.
- I've tweaked the "Next game" button:
  - The number in brackets is the number of games in the queue that are *not* the game you're currently viewing.
  - If you're in the last game of your queue, the button will simply say "Viewing last game."
  - Once you've submitted your move in that last game, the button will then read "Back to dashboard." But when you click it, it does actually refresh the queue first. So if an opponent made a move while you were making other moves, clicking the button will still take you to that game directly, despite what the button text says.

Let me know if you encounter any issues.

I've added a "Join once" button to the tournament page. Joining a tournament using this button means you will only be registered in the next tournament but not any later iterations. (You'll know you've "joined once" if you see an asterisk after your name in the participant list, as in the screen capture.) "Join recurring" does the normal behaviour of adding you to each following iteration until you withdraw. The withdraw button has also been relabelled "Withdraw from next" to make it clearer. You cannot withdraw from a tournament that has already started (other than resigning your games).

The purpose of the automated tournaments is to keep a steady flow of games you enjoy, but apparently there is also a desire to try a new game without having to remember to withdraw afterwards. Hopefully this helps, though it does make the interface a little more cluttered. Further feedback and suggestions are welcome. Thanks for playing!

The way the site generates thumbnails has finally been updated.
- Once a day, the site chooses a random active instance of a game (or a random completed game if no games are currently being played).
- The current state is rendered in light and dark modes.
- The thumbnails you see in the browser will adjust based on the colour mode you've chosen.

This means that thumbnails will more accurately reflect actual game play and will change from day to day. It also *greatly* reduces the size of the payload your browser downloads when you visit the site.

The rendering doesn't know about user settings, so they are still rendered using the default colours, and if you've edited your "colour context" (very few have), then the thumbnails may look a little odd because they're rendered using the default contexts. If you encounter any broken or otherwise weird thumbnails, please let me know. Enjoy!

I have now added basic websocket support to the site. This doesn't change anything about how the backend currently functions, but this lays the foundation for more real-time features in the future. Two new features are available now, though:
- Next to the button for toggling colour modes, there's now a wifi icon and a number. That number is the number of players currently using the site at that moment (including yourself).
- More importantly, though, games will now auto-reload when a move is made or a chat is added, whether you're participating or observing. Basically, if you're looking at the page, it will refresh when someone changes the state. This will hopefully make playing realtime games more bearable. I've removed the "periodic refresh" button as a result.

Let me know if you encounter any issues. Enjoy!
